There are lounge chairs placed out on the lawns facing the ocean where we spent quite a bit of time in the late afternoons when we could find some shade. I would say that these are the main reasons for staying at the hotel. On the other hand, This Marriott is listed as a category 7 but in no way is it comparable to some category 6 marriotts that we have stayed in. It is undergoing renovations and has been for some time. One of their pools and most of the shops and their restaurant, the Hula Moons are closed. We were located in the Tower and had to use an elevator to get to the ground level in order to reach the pool and beach area. The elevator was in deplorable condition and is used by the maids and other hotel employees to transport their cleaning supplies. Our bathroom was tiny and contained only a very deep tub, no shower stall. a major disappointment. There is no direct access to the beach. There was no shade by the pools that were open and consequently if you want to spend any time there you must get there early to obtain one of the few beach umbrellas or pay $15/day for a cabana/lounge. The room was clean and bright and although the furniture was not comfortable and the balcony was crowded with just a table and 2 plastic chairs, the bed was very comfortable. Parking, if not using the valet service, was inconvenient. Since we paid for it with our Marriott Rewards Points it was not a total loss and in spite of our complaints, we loved Maui. Would we stay there again? I don't think so, we would probably opt for a condo rental.

Reviews.Title: “Great Experience”
Reviews.Author: amijen4
Reviews.Content: We just returned from 3 Days at the Marriott Wailea and were concerned going due to the reviews about the construction and poor service. We were upgraded upon check in and had an ocean view room and was it a view. We paid for the upgrade in Waikiki for a Diamond Head Beach view and felt robbed after we checked in here. We experienced minimal construction noise and had a great room with a great view. The view from the pool and the only restaurant open on property were breathtaking. Service was impeccable. From check in through housekeeping and bartenders/waiters/waitresses and pool side service. SPA /gym were the only things lacking. Gave 4 vice 5 stars because SPA and gym were in Hotel rooms due to construction and we were looking to get pampered while there (we skipped that plan. Hotel will be even nicer once construction complete, but we still had a great experience there and plan to return.

Reviews.Title: “Expected more for honeymooners”
Reviews.Author: rosebud8506
Reviews.Content: My husband and I chose our stay at the Marriott Wailea as part 2 of our honeymoon excursion. We stayed on Oahu for 3 days and spent the remainder of our trip (7 days) in Maui. We chose this hotel over the Renassaince simply becuase it had a better rating between the two and was within our price range. We arrived and immediatly were greeted with a shell necklace - nice, but everywhere in Hawaii typically does this. They were friendly, and check in was as long as it usually is. We had a lovely ocean view (which was probably the highlight of this hotel overall and made the stay somewhat positive). Right away my husband asks as we are ready to get the key and head on to our room, "I have to ask, is there anything special for honeymooners?". The desk clerk said "Yes, do you like champagne? We can send a bottle up right away". Well, I can tell you that we did not immedetialy receive that bottle of champagne, and I had to call at least 3 times down to the front desk and "remind" them about us. The last call, they finally mentioned "Oh, they usually deliver it in the evenings." I think it was not a very welcoming jesture, and then it came to the point where I felt like I was begging them to follow through. Very dissappointed.... They also do not inform you of the $15.00 sur-service fee that you are paying everyday. They make it out to be optional, and if you do not read the many phamphlets that they hand out to you, then you would not even be aware that there is one. This fee gives you something like 10% off your meals at the hotel and then a percentage off the luau. Had we known this, we would have drank the bottles of Figi water that kept piling up in our room (we thought they were only for those who chose the resort passport) I can tell you that we skipped the luau, as we were in Oahu and visited the Polynesian Cultural Center and enjoyed their luau immensley. Like they mentioned above, if you've seen one luau, you've seen them all. I'd like the also mention the renovations were still being underway, and in their website they did note that it would be completed in July of 2006 - hardly finished by the time we were there which was 8/10 - 8/18. The lay out of this hotel is not for those who cannot get around easily without an elevator. Our room was on the 3rd floor and it was a workout each time (espcially since you are walking to and from the beach and pool) its a lot of walking. We opted for a deep tissue massage at the Mandara Spa - which is rediculously overpriced, but neither one of us had done it before and it was our honeymoon, so we gave it a try. While the massage itself was relaxing, it is not in the normal location. It is in a basic guest room with the beds removed! I was a little disappointed that it was not in the normal location (most likley due to the renovations) and thought for the price we were paying, they should have gived us an "inconvenience" discount. It seemed cheap. We were expecting a bit more from the pool area - I got the feeling the pool was not cleaned every day and it was disappointingly lukewarm - not something that is refreshing after basking in the sun. The guys at the towel hut were annoying. If you were just going to get a towel, you were getting hounded to "Take the Maui Jim Challenge". My husband owns a pair of his own Maui Jim sunglasses and they STILL hounded him every morning as if he were a new guest. So much for a sales pitch. Eating: Anyplace you go, you will easily drop $40.00 or more for a breakfast or a lunch out for two if you eat at the hotel restaurants. We found the Whalers General Store at the Shops of Wailea to be a nice option for grabbing a bagel or hot breakfast and you can spend under $10.00 for two ( a much better option). They also have deli sandwiches and such. Overall, the stay was as I would expect it to be for a stay in Florida or someplace on the mainland, I was expecting much more for Hawaii.

Reviews.Title: “Great for a category 3 hotel”
Reviews.Author: Travel_now1234
Reviews.Content: Just returned from the Wailea Marriott and the stay was at best, satisfactory. Construction was very evident - dirty, dusty corridor carpets, elevators that need major overhauling - especially the tower elevator leading to the beach, inoperable washing machines and dryers (expect only 1 of each to be working), a "fitness" center containing about 9-10 clearly old machines squeezed into a converted room and swimming pools were something you would expect at a $69 night motel, not $300+ category 6-7 that Marriott claims this hotel to be. On the other hand, if you can overlook the obvious deficiencies, the location of the hotel is top notch. Unlike the Grand Wailea, which undeniably is the better hotel, the setting at the Marriott Wailea is more intimate and much less crowded. Unlike some of the other reviews, I found the housekeeping, parking and front desk staff to be quite responsive. Save your dining money by eating at the many surrounding restaurants. Our top choices: Mama's Fish House - absolutely a uniquely wonderful experience Sansei - had dinner here 3 times, its that good especially when discounts of 25-50% are offered for early bird (5:30-6pm) dinners Shaka Pizza in Kihei - pizza pretty decent for a quick meal w/kids For those who want to try authentic desserts - Homemaid bakery in Wailuku on Main St. Get there early as most popular items are gone by about 3-4PM. Despite the fanfare, found A Taste of Saigon (Vietnamese) to be a big disappointment. Fish was overcooked and the rest of the food was bland. Perhaps the chef was having an off day but disappointed enough to not return. Unless convenience is a major objective, suggest booking your activities (Kayaking, snorkeling, flying, biking etc) at various expedia.fun outlets. Found them quite knowledgible and reasonably priced. Trip highlights: - drive to Haleakala - boat ride/snorkeling at Molokini through Whale foundation. Very knowledgible hosts and very organized. Kids had a blast sliding and jumping in from the boat. - Kayaking/snorkeling from Makena Landing - used Kelli outfitters. Lots of fish, some turtles and can see Tiger Woods new house being built. - Drive South past Makena landing (about 3-4 miles) to see some incredible lava landscaping. First thought was why would someone dig up the land this way quickly gave way to recognizing land in its most raw form. - 30 North past Kapalua - drive very similar to Hwy 1 along S. and Central CA coast. Spectacular scenary - watch out when the state road ends and turns into a one lane "road" for about 15 miles - definitely not for the faint of heart. If this is a once in a lifetime experience, book your stay somewhere else. Lower your expectations on the Hotel and you'll be fine.

Reviews.Title: “Definitive Report: 3 Star Resort; 5 Star Location”
Reviews.Author: Talldarkhandsomest
Reviews.Content: My fiance' and I had looked forward to this vacation for 6 months and were greatly disappointed. I feel let down and mislead by the Marriott website, Marriott management and also by the previous reviewers of this property on tripadvisor for not being thorough and critical enough of a resort that charges 4-6 hundred per night. Marriott lists this property as a "category 7", this is as high as their system goes. NO WAY. Let me say that I am a Marriott Timeshare owner and stay at many resorts that are 3-5 stars for business and pleasure (I work for an international wine company.) I have heard much about the ongoing renovation. It didn't cause much noise in our wing (the haleakala tower) but it severely curbed the resorts dining options. Also, the hotel elevators in the tower wing look horrendous--what you'd expect in a budget Vegas hotel. I know transporting renovation materials causes a mess and puts scratches all over but the guest experience need not be affected if you set aside elevators for this purpose and kept certain ones for guests only. I can't believe management allows guests to use the "beach access" elevator--it looks like it went through a hurricane. What is very dissapointing is that management chose to keep this resort open and to continue charging regular expensive rates for a much degraded experience. No discounts and the resort had the huevos rancheros to actually charge a $15 per day resort fee! An outrage. The better option would have been to completely close the resort for 2 months and bring in hordes of workers to do it very fast so the guest wasn't exposed. Instead, Marriott chose to continue making a buck by delivering a poor product. The physical structure of the resort is 3 star--it's location is 5 star all the way. So why did I give this just 1 star? EMPLOYEE ATTITUDE, period. In my view, with the exception of the very good valets, the staff has given up for now and this place is devoid of Aloha Spirit. We didn't encounter outright rudeness, but no one made us feel welcome or seem to appreciate us. The front desk staff were sullen and did not smile on every occasion I had to interact with them. I asked for an upgrade and was denied flatly. If I wanted it, It was $175 for full ocean view and $300 for Ocean front. We had plenty of ocean view from our room but had to look out over the roof units and AC units of the main lobby. Room #817. One day at the kids pool my fiance' asked the towel attendant why the slide was closed and he didn't even look up from reading the newspaper while retorting "lifeguard must be on break." On day #1 I left the housekeeper a $5 dollar tip and a nice note of thanks that was genuinely warm and she responded in no way at all. No cutely folded towels, no chocolate dipped strawberries, not even a note with a smiley face on it! I tipped her the same amount two days later and got the same result. I really felt like I was the one doing all the work trying to bring Aloha to this resort. I left two bottles of expensive wine when we checked out for the housekeeper with a note for her to enjoy them-- she really seemed to need a drink to loosen up. At checkout, I gave a $50 bottle of Cabernet to the clerk and instructed her to give it to the next honeymooners--her look and reply seemed to imply I was annoying her. My stomach turned. You would get more hospitality from Tom Boudet at Motel 6--atleast he'd "leave the light on for you." I assure you I am no snob; I'm just not a pushover either. I do have expectations when rates are stratospheric. Here's some specifics: ROOMS: The renovated rooms where clean and adequate--not gorgeous but of slightly above average size; I would estimate 425 Sq. feet. Bathroom a bit small. Yes, the bed is terrific in every regard. Patio furniture is cheap. No seperate shower stall, just a bathtub. By the way, in pictures I've seen that Marriott is showing off it appears they are leading you to believe they have flat screen plasma TV's--not so. Technically, the screens are "flat" but the unit itself is large and not slender. A cooler is provided for use--it kept stuff cold. I agree with another reviewer that the towels are budget quality. They do provide good quality robes and a small safe for valuables. GROUNDS: Well maintained, very lush but lacking in bright color; mostly just green. Their are some water features but they aren't very impressive. The view from the open air lobby is very beautiful of the sea, unfortunately the lobby is very plain and lacks atmosphere. The resort is very spread out but it's nice to walk in the balmy breezes. Since there is no direct resort beach, loungers are put out by the rocks and provide nice spots for sunset watching. We saw some turtles playing in the surf. POOLS: Very ordinary for the adults. Not very big and no special features. (OK, it's an infinity pool but who cares!?) The kids pool was pretty cool as they have two fairly large slides that I had fun playing on. One of them is twisty and the other shoots you out into 10 feet deep water from a 5 foot dropoff. :) The kids pool also has a snack bar where you can get shaved ice--yummy. LUAU: Advertised as the "best", as are many things in Maui for that matter. Every single bar on the island makes the BEST Mai Tai, hhhmmm. If you have seen one Luau, you have seen them all, trust me. By the way, all of the resort luau's are so open you would have to be quite dense to actually pay $60-75 per person to have an actual seat and eat the food. You can see everything without paying--you just don't get a folding chair or poorly tasting food and poi--nasty anyhow. RESTAURANTS: We only ate at the poolside bar on our first night because we arrived at 9pm. Slow service but the food quality was good. Very outdated however. It's called the KUMU lounge and they served drinks in glasses circa 1980. I know it's by the pool, so the glasses have to be plastic but can't you find good plastic cocktail glasses when guests are paying these exorbitant rates? Main restaurant, Hula Moons is still under renovation. EXCURSIONS: Since you won't want to be spending much time at this character devoid resort you have many exciting options off premise. Maui is beautiful and worth exploring. We found a place called Activity Warehouse in Lahaina and booked 4 excursions that cost us only $204 each total. We had a 5 hour snorkel trip on the Leilani out of a nearby harbor (Maleea?) The crew was great--Paul and Sean were very cool and hospitable. We went to Molokini and Turtle Town. Great water clarity at Molokini with tons of fish to see. Some saw an 8 ft. white tip reef shark--awesome. Sea Turtles are everywhere in Maui--we saw a ton of them on "Big Beach" in Makena; which is just south of Wailea. Try to go to molokini on a calm wind day. We did a tandem 8 minute parasail ride in Lahaina that was serene, exciting, slightly scary and beautiful. I highly recommend it. Our boat crew was great and funny and very mischievious--they really loved to slow the boat down and "dunk" you in the ocean before they reeled you back in! It was fun but I kept on thinking that it wouldn't be so fun if a tiger shark managed to time his snack appropriately! :) When we were up the water is so blue and clear we could clearly see a large barracuda swimming below. We booked the 38 mile downhill Haleakala bike ride and sunset viewing but we skipped it as we couldn't pull ourselves out of the awesome bed at 2 in the morning! We did a 45 minute helicopter ride up to Haleakala and around the east in Hana. It was slightly scary too during turbulence. Those sitting up front by the pilot will also have much better views. I would still recommend it highly though. Alex air on the backside of the airport did a good job. RECOMENDATION: We visited two other resorts for comparison sake; the Renaissance (owned by Marriott) and the Grand Wailea. These resorts bookend the Marriott. Do yourself a very big favor. If you were going to stay at the Marriott on "points" or as part of a Marriott rewards program, as we were, switch to the Renaissance. It was absolutely gorgeous and the atmosphere was terrific. We got drinks from the lobby bar and watched the sunset while we fumed over how terrible our resort was in comparison. The Renaissance lobby is gorgeous with traditional hawaiian music playing. The grounds are also much better looking. And guess what? The Renaissance is actually listed as a category 6 and is less expensive than the Marriott! Change your reservation to the Renaissance or you will be very sorry. Or the other option is to spend more money and upgrade to the Grand Wailea. It is much more crowded but the pools are amazing--truly waterpark like. The grounds are simply amazing. You will have a serious case of resort envy if you go there. I know this is a "downer" review. When I was reading these reviews prior to my trip I didn't want to hear the negatives either. I wish I would have listened to the critical reviews!! If you are used to staying at budget hotels you will like the resort; but any kind of seasoned, upscale traveler will be greatly dissapointed. Shame on the resort for not considerably discounting rates while under construction! The Marriott is definitely the most blase' resort in all of Wailea. You are right next to the shops of Wailea--eat there. Other great dining experiences were at Ruth's Chris at the shops. Our waiter, Padgett, was amazing. An old Four Seasons guy who was a consumate pro. Wonderful and polite. Ask for him and tell him I sent you. (I tried to give him a bottle of Chalk Hill Merlot but he couldn't accept it due to local law) You can't bring wine into any Maui restaurant by the way, FYI. Sansei in Kihei was wonderful for sushi. Sunday and Monday for the first hour everything except alcohol is half price! Get there early! We got there 45 minutes before opening and a line had already formed. By the time the doors opened 150 people were lined up! Roy's in Kihei had good food but the place itself was not aesthetically pleasing at all. Roy's on the mainland are beautiful and oppulent--on Maui they look like cafeterias! For a real cool dining experience local style, go just past the Maui Prince hotel to the south and you will come upon a roadside Van/Shack called "JAWZ" Island Style Tacos. It was delicious, inexpensive and unpretentious--refreshing after all the ridiculously overpriced meals. That's about it for now. Feel free to contact me to discuss further and I'll give you as many details as I can. Have fun on Maui! :)

Reviews.Title: “Oceanside at the Wailea Marriott”
Reviews.Author: targiro
Reviews.Content: My wife, 10 month old son and I spent 10 days at the Wailea Marriott and found the resort to be "nice." It is not the most impressive hotel in South Maui (I suggest the Four Seasons, Grand Wailea or Fairmont if that is what you are interested in) but does allow you to stay at beautiful location, oceanside, and not feel crowded. The hotel is "campus" style with several smaller "hales" (units) that contain 20 - 30 rooms. This allows for guest to be spread out across the property. There is one large tower, however, we did not stay in this area. There are several pools (which need some modernization which should be coming soon) that allow for the guest to lounge close to their hotel rooms. The beach areas to the north and south (a one minute walk) are great and allow for great access to the Pacific. While the hotel is completing its renovations, construction noise and disturbances were non existent and never an issue. The renovated rooms are comfortable. One small complaint...since the rooms have tile floors, this allows for the guest staying above you to make a lot of noise by doing normal things like moving a desk chair, setting anything on the floor or closing the sliding glass door. For meals, I suggest avoiding the hotel unless you want to spend $24 per person for a breakfast buffet or $14 for a hamburger. The food in the evening isn't much better. An alternative would be to Cheeseburger Islandstyle, Maui Tacos, Sansei (great Japanese restaurant in Kihei), Italian restaraunt next to Sansei, Cinnamon Roll shop in Kihei for breakfast or stop by the Safeway and stock up on snacks, fresh produce and other items to avoid the $$$$ at the Marriott. Each room has a cooler, so there will be space to keep food fresh. The best restaurants in Maui are Mama's Fish House, Buzz's Wharf (for lunch) and Kimo's or other options in Lahaina town. Overall, we enjoyed our stay. This side of the island is less crowded versus Kaanapalli. For evening entertainment, you would be best driving 30 - 45 minutes to Lahaina for people watching, more choices for meals and entertainment.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort, beautiful vacation!”
Reviews.Author: LFoley
Reviews.Content: My husband was attending a conference at the Wailea Marriott in February, 2004, and I tagged along to make it a fun vacation for the both of us. We arrived at the Marriott around 10pm after our flight, and we were greeted with heavenly-smelling leis and very friendly bellboys. The front desk check-in was smooth and fast, and they upgraded us from a garden-view room to an ocean-view which was a very pleasant surprise. The lobby area is open-air and has spectacular views. The room was nothing particularly special, but it was clean and neat. I don't need much more than that since I'm not one to stay much in a room when I'm visiting paradise! The next morning while my husband was in conference, I explored the grounds and, forgetting about the sun since it was such a mild and pleasant temperature, got a nice sunburn. The landscaping is lovely, and so many things were in bloom. The beach was a short little walk away, but since I'm not much of a sand and surf person, we only went there once. I'm used to the expansive, sugar-white beaches of the gulf coast, so I have to say that I wasn't all that impressed. It seemed small and not very good for swimming. But, like I said, I'm not much of a beach person, so I probably don't know what I'm talking about. The black sand beaches on the other side of the island (road to Hana) were much more interesting to me. Other than the conference-based breakfasts, we didn't eat in any of the hotel's dining establishments. Too pricey for our tastes. We did get their in-room dinner special twice, though. It's a great deal with quite a bit of food, and it can be utterly romantic. They come in and set up everything for you on your lanai. We ate after dark with the sound of the waves crashing, the tiki torches flickering, and a live band out by the pool playing Hawaiian music. It was just wonderful! Our other meals were gotten at The Shops at Wailea just steps away or on our island explorations. Keawakapu is just right around the corner by car and has lots of choices. Speaking of The Shops at Wailea, I spent some time there during the afternoons my husband was in conference. Lots of great upscale shopping as well as the ever-present ABC store where you can get pretty much anything you need. There's a great souvenier store/deli on the ground level by the main fountain that has huge delicious sandwiches - great for lunch. There was construction going on at the resort while we were there, but it was on the opposite side from our room, so we didn't even notice it. The pool area was really nothing special which was a disappointment. I was hoping for dramatic waterfalls or something like that. Watch out for the towel hut! They'll try to sell you some expensive sunglasses when you're just trying to get a towel. Overall, this is a lovely resort and was perfect for the kind of vacation I was interested in. It was a nice home base and place to relax in between island adventures. Speaking of adventures - definitely do Haleakala at sunrise and the Road to Hana. If you like even more wild driving, take the road around the back of Haleakala even though they claim it's unpaved and not for vehicles without 4 wheel drive. It was really not that bad, and we were in a Sebring convertible. Lots of fantastic view. For some really wild roads, take 30 around West Maui Mountain. My husband says he'd never do anything like that again, but it was an experience I'd never trade!

Reviews.Title: “Wailea with the family”
Reviews.Author: Peter2150
Reviews.Content: The hotel is wonderful, albeit it will be better when the construction is done. You do not really notice it and the workers try hard to stay low key. Some of the dust and dirt can be a bother. The rooms were great and new, the beds are delightful. We liked that the beachs were of the side as it cut down on traffic and noise in front of the ocean. The view and grounds are out of a hollywood set and the grounds are well kept up. Pools were very average, kid pool area was fun with the slide. The food is great, however one dining outlet got old. Pricing is very high however portions are large so with kids we could split courses. We also shopped a bit at the shops of Wailea which helped. The Luau was fun , allbeit expensive and one day we treked up the coast to try para sailing which the hotel set up and charged it to the room. Internet access is .50 cents a minute so watch out if you use the business center. Overall a great vacation and we will go back.

Reviews.Title: “Not very pleased...”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband I and just returned from a stay at the Wailea Marriott (stayed there June 22 through June 25) and were terribly dissappointed in the resort. We were under the impression that the renovations would be almost complete and this was not the case! As far as we could tell only the rooms and the main lobby had been redone. The first room that we were given was in a building that was in the midst of being renovated and we had to step over construction to get our room!! We spent one night in that room and then asked to be moved. The new room/building was better but the hallways were filthy -- room service trays not picked up promptly, filled trash bags and a large trash barrel filled with dirty towels sat at the end of our hall for over 24 hours!! The carpet in the halls was dirty and the tile was filthy. On the tile stairs leading up to the main lobby, there was bright red chewed gum smack in the middle of the steps for the duratiobn of our stay, old cigarettes as well. The pool is in desperate need of reonvations and we could not stand to lounge there or swim. It seemed dirty. The concrete surround the pool is cracked and just plain gray cement. The lounge chairs and tables are old and dirty and the towels they give you were old as well. The rooms are nice. The bed was great but we could not fully enjoy our sleep there because we could not get the room cool enough for our liking. My husband and I both woke up hot each night. Marriott should close this resort until ALL the renovations are complete. Until then, the resort is a shame to the Marriott name.

Reviews.Title: “Not a regular Marriott hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel was not exactly what we expected from a Marriott property. First, at the time when we were booking the trip the hotel advertised that the remodeling would be over in May of 2006, but as we found a month prior to the trip, the construction was to continue through the end of the fall. It was too late for us to change our plans. Our first unpleasant experience at the hotel was with the check-in time (4 PM). Even though we specifically requested to be checked in earlier, this service was not granted to us and we had to wait up to 4 pm sharp to get keys to our room. Touring the property we noticed that the amenities are not new, the spa consists of only two ex-guest rooms, there is only one restaurant open and the night life is almost non-existent at the hotel. A resort fee of $15/day was neither advertised nor justified. The hotel does not have a direct beach access. The beds were wonderful and the room decorating was new but nothing special. It felt like most of this hotel was temporarily out of service while we were there. I am not sure if I ever go back to this hotel after this visit.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular Coastline”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel with my family the week after Easter. The renovations were still taking place, but I did not find the noise to be a problem. They are mainly working on room renovations right now, and the noise it limited to during the day. Our room was recently renovated. The rooms all seem to have the same look now, off white textured wall paper, dark wood doors, door frames and furniture, some modern art on the walls and ceramic tile flooring. Beds were extremely comfortable. I have 3 children (3, 6, and 9) and they enjoyed the pools. Childrens pool has a fun play area and 2 good slides even fun for adults. All pools were not too crowded, I imagine because so many of the rooms were being renovated and unoccupied. We had buffet breakfast one day at the restaurant. Price was not too bad, the whole bill was $40 for the 5 of us due to a discount you get from the mandatory $15 resort fee. Buffet was just OK, nothing special. The Marriott has no beach, but its lava rock coast is beautiful. There are plenty of lounge chairs set up on the grass by the rocks. It was a very peaceful place to relax. Two beaches are just a short walk in either direction. Wailea Beach to the right is very nice. Good for snorkeling as well. Don't rent snorkels from the resort, much cheaper at Maui Dive Shop at the Shops at Wailea - even cheaper if you drive up to Kihei. As far as dining, Cheeseburger in Paradise at the Shops is great, Sansei in Kihei very good for sushi and seafood. Mama's Fish House on the other side of the island is excellent. Kind of pricey, but very good food and great old Hawaii atmosphere. For shave ice, go to Maui Espresso - it's a little stand in Kihei on S. Kehei Rd in the Rainbow Mall shopping center. Also, there's a very mainland style shopping center on the main road going into Wailea - Safeway, Starbucks, Borders Books. Roy's is in this shopping center too. In summary - we enjoyed the Wailea Marriott - pros : nice rooms, uncrowded, great location, beautiful coastline. Cons: food on hotel site not great, some construction noise and eyesores, no high speed internet in rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Marriott in Wailea - always a good choice”
Reviews.Author: abubnic
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Marriott for a week in January. This was our second stay at this hotel, while attending a conference at the Grand Wailea. We prefer this hotel to the Grand Wailea because the parking situation is much better and it is a quick walk to the stores. You can also walk along the ocean to get to the conference meetings. Parking was more limited than usual during this visit due to construction going on at the hotel. But it was still easier than parking at the Grand Wailea, which always seems filled to capacity due to conference bookings. We had an ocean room in the Marriott towers with a terrific view. There are not many dining options here, but there are plenty of local places to eat so it really doesn't matter. We'd definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Great place, beautiful view”
Reviews.Author: rosewood
Reviews.Content: My family and I spent 12 nights at this resort (includes two teenage boys and a husband). We all had a wonderful time. We booked a garden view room but were using my husbands points and were upgraded to ocean front room. This hotel is under renovation but it did not have an affect on our stay. there were a few times we heard a jack-hammer during the day but we would just move to another pool and that appeared to only last a few days. It appeared the staff and construction workers made a huge effort to be unobtrusive and courteous. Breakfast was great by the pool and a nice view. My only complaint is that there are only two washer/dryers. this resort is so spread out that if you are on the other side from the laundry what a hike with dirty clothes. While we were there my son and husband both got food poisoning from a local restautant(Bada Bing). My son was sick all over the room (will not go into detail) thank goodness for tile floors. Anyway they came and gave us a new rug, new comforter etc. were great about the problem. AAA+ friendly staff, bed were soooo comfortable. the conciergie was great help in advising things for us to do with teenagers. Highly recommed the America II sail (when they say you will get wet they are serious), zip line, rent snorkel gear and boogie boards for the week at Maui Dive shop in the mall at wailea. I also would recommend the laui in Lahaina not at the hotel (big difference). Must read is a blue book titled Maui revealed. My boys were tired of me quoting this book until we used its advice and tried to find the redwood forest what and adventure and trekking to red beach (on a cliff) in Hana (drive yourself). I was ready to hide the blue book as it came to be know, My boys loved every minute of the adventures.

Reviews.Title: “A wonderful stay”
Reviews.Author: allobosc
Reviews.Content: We stayed here in Nov. 05 over Thanksgiving break for our honeymoon. We had an oceanview room and absolutely loved it. We knew that it was next door to the mega-resorts, but we really enjoyed the peace and tranquility of this hotel. The renovations weren't bothersome at all except for the noise one morning, but we were on our way out anyways. The old room style was typical and nothing too special but it did have a great view. There was only one restaurant when we were there but it was good food and allowed us to see the other restaurants Maui has to offer. We did love the breakfast though. The pool was not that exciting, but for us it was great. There was hardly anyone at the hotel and we practically had the pool to ourselves the whole time. We personally loved the rocky coast as opposed to the beach coast. Wailea beach was only a minute walk anyways. The location was excellent for shopping and the beach! I should note that we spent the last two days of our honeymoon at the Grand Wailea, and while impressed by all the glitz, we both agree it was too crowded and noisey. We would go back to the Marriott in a second and are anxious to see there new changes. Also, the renovations/construction going on are not just going on at the Mariott, there is a new condo place being built right behind it and next to the Grand Wailea.

Reviews.Title: “Good but not great”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I read all the hotel reviews before checking in so I knew to request a renovated room when I checked in. Our room was a good location - near the front of hotel - so it was convenient when we were coming and going. It was clean and the bed was fantastic. Because the hotel is under renovation it's pretty empty. We had the pool, by the kiddie area, to ourselves several times. The pools were OK but really cold. Getting in the ocean was warmer! The staff was friendly and accomodating with a late checkout request. The grounds seemed lacking - especially compared to the Grand Wailea and Renaissance. The hotel was adequate but for the price I would rather stay at the Grand Wailea, Renaissance or Fairmont Kea Lani. I'd compare prices at those others before booking at the Marriott, again.

Reviews.Title: “A nice place to stay”
Reviews.Author: mauilvr
Reviews.Content: We came directly fron the Sheraton so the Marriott had a lot to stand up to. When we arrived they put us in a room that had noise from the backing up beeps of the equipment unloading supplies and over looking their parking lot. After we unpacked, the backing noise was driving me crazy so I went to the front desk and they said the only room they had left was in Hale seven by were they were renovating and it would be worse. So I declined. The next day the backingup noise started at 8:00 and so we went and asked for the change to Hale 7 and boy we were glad we did. There was zero noise from construction. Sure you seen equipment, but that did not bother us. We were right done the ocean and by the kids pool which was nice for the kids. Also by the area that they did there luau a couple nights, but we always left to eat around that time so it did not bother us. The room was renovated tastefully and had everything you needed. The feather toppers were taken off because we got too hot but the bed was still comfy. We found the resort quite spread out but it also did not feel busy then. I did not find that the Marriott was a clean around the resort a the Sheraton but not a big deal. The Wailea beach was a minute walk Ulua about 4 minutes from our room. The Wailea beach has the most silky sand that I have ever had under foot. Spent 3 days there and one day at the Polo beach which the boys liked for boogie boarding. BIG waves. If we had not been moved from the first room, we might have hated this hotel. The new location was magnificent. Everyone in our party said in the end that it was a great place to stay. Nicest beaches on the island, yes even better than Sheraton!! Do not stop your stay just because there is renovating going on. If you find yourself in a room that you do not like they will try their best to make it right.

Reviews.Title: “Somewhat ok”
Reviews.Author: doesntwork
Reviews.Content: We were in Waikiki when the rains hit and didnt stop so decided to fly to Maui. Called the Marriott and the reservationist made res for us but did not tell us the check in time was so late (4:00) thus we waited for 2 hours. We were not told the hotel was under renovation and when asked where our room would be the desk clerk informed us it was between two rooms being renovated and they would be working from 8-5 on those rooms. We asked for something better and were given an ocean front room on the right side of the complex. We were also told that the hotel had 2 beaches but not told that the beaches were not in front of the hotel. As mentioned in other reviews, it is a large complex. The beds were wonderful and the room decorating was new but nothing special. Food was adequate as there was only one restaurant open during renovation. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Only one of their shops was open during renovation. It felt like most of this hotel was temporarily out of service while we were there. The location was super; right next to SHops of Wailea. Grounds were very nice. I'd go back and give it another try after renovations are complete.

Reviews.Title: “Great place, good people.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This place was great. My wife and I stayed only three nights since I was there for business. The new tower room was great with a great view of the ocean and the whales. We had room service every morning and the food was good also, a bit spendy but what isn't in Maui. The concierge set us up with a Luau (onsite)and whale watching (Kaikanani) and they both were superb. The bed was outstanding we both have very sensitive backs and slept well every night. The room was very clean each day. The people that work there are very friendly and helpful. We would definetly recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Wailea Marriott”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: 4 ladies celebrating birthdays met in Maui and stayed at the Wailea Marriott. It was beautiful. The rooms were clean and the beds were awesome. So comfortable. The continental breakfast was outstanding and the free Mimosas hit the spot. The pools were clean and the staff was friendly. I would definitely recommend staying here to all who are considering it. The hotel also has a shopping mall attached to it for your convenience. For a great excursion, go snorkeling at Molokini. We had a fabulous time. Have fun and Aloha.

Reviews.Title: “Good time at the Wailea Marriott”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I have just returned from a week at the Wailea Marriott. I stayed there four years ago when it was still the Wailea Outrigger. The hotel is very nice. Yes, they are undergoing a major renovation, but for the most part the work was limited to day time hours (8am - 5pm). We were a family of four with two children (10 & 13). We enjoyed the children's pool and water slides. We enjoyed the beaches next door. The room was very comfortable and yes the beds are very comfortable. Hotel service was fine. We really never needed anything. Because I still needed to do some work while on the road high speed internet access is very important. They didn't have any access in the rooms (other than dial up). They did have wireless in the large open air lobby (not a bad place to do some work) and they did have a dedicated room with a few desktop computers and a couple of cat5 lan connections. Although we all enjoyed our stay, we have decided the next time we go to Maui we will look into a condo. The room did have a small refrigerator but not large enough or cold enough for serious food. I am not knocking this hotel for that. I knew going in, just noting that in future stays I can see the benefit of having a kitchen. We paid $267.00 plus a resort fee of $15.00. With taxes it was over $300 per night for an ocean view. And the view was beautiful.

Reviews.Title: “Great Beds!!”
Reviews.Author: syxx1000
Reviews.Content: Stayed here in early February with my wife. The resort is definitely a 4 star resort right now as far facilities go. The pools were nothing special and actually quite cold, so we did not use them. As mentioned before, there is no beach directly at the resort, but one on either side of the resort. I recommend the Wailea Beach towards the left side if you're facing the ocean. Much larger but also more corwded, but the water was clearer and a little warmer. Yes the resort is under renovation, but for the most part, you will not notice it. They are working on the far left side of the resort, so just try to get a room closer to lobby or as close as you can get, and you'll be fine. Our package came with a nightly appetizer at the Kumu bar and grill poolside. They were actually pretty good and we took advantage of them daily. We did not eat at any other restaurants on site, but ate at Roys in Kihei, and at Maui Thai also in Kihei. Kihei is only a quick 10 min drive and has just about everything you need including a Safe Way for any groceries. Plenty of restaurants of all kind there. Which bringe me to the best part of the stay...... The rooms!! Make sure you get one of the renovated rooms...they are beautiful..very nicely decked out. If possible try to get a corner suite, which is much larger. We were in room 700 and it was excellent. The beds will probably be the best beds you will ever sleep on in any hotel. I have slept on the Westin Heavenly Sleeper, and thay dont even compare to these ones. I didnt see one of the older rooms, but they did tell me that they should be done with all the rooms by June, so if youre looking top go after that, it wont be an issue. The concierge at the Marriott, Stacy, was excellent. She is very helpful and if you have any questions, you can contact her before you get there, and she can book any trip you want for you. Also did the Luau at the MArriott, which was pretty good. Had a fun time and would recommend getting there early. Another great part of this resort was the lack of kids there. If youre going as a couple and prefer not to have kids running around, then I'd recommend this hotel. If you have a family with little ones, then I'd go elsewhere until they have all their renovations done, since there isnt much in terms of facilities for kids. We took a stroll to the Grand Wailea next door, and if you can afford to splurge, then definitely go there. It has a lot of kids running around though, and actually gives you a good reminder of how quiet the Marriott is. However the actual resort of Grand Wailea is superb, and beautiful and definitely worth seeing even if youre not staying there. Overall, had a great stay at the Marriott and I'd absoloutely recommend it if you knew that you were not going to spend much time at the resort duirng the days, but wanted to a very nice new room for the nights.

Reviews.Title: “Here's the real deal!”
Reviews.Author: TravelSnob1
Reviews.Content: Ok, here's the real deal from a travel snob. The newly renovated rooms are very nice, close to a 4 seasons quality but not quite. Surprising the renovated room didnt have a phone next to the bed. The non-renovated rooms are fair but mine had a shower that had filthy grout. The pool is fine but not one that makes you want to take a plunge. The design for the new pool is an infinity pool which looks impressive. The lobby could use a renovation as well and for the well traveled person, there is nothing that makes you impressed. The hotel seems much smaller than the Grand Wailea which has too many rooms and kids screaming by the pool. This is definitely a more relaxing hotel, but I will deal with the loudness of the pool for the better hotel. The 4 sesasons is the best of the bunch but still not impressive for a 4 seasons resort property. For those of you that know the 4 Seasons bali and expect this level of property, you will be disappointed. I do like the free internet service next to the lobby with 4 computers. I would recommend a higher floor if you have an ocean view since the view will be more impressive.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Room but lousy hotel layout”
Reviews.Author: taylor0616
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed there during December 2005. We were given a room that had not been renovated and after seeing it, we asked if we could have one of the newly renovated ones. They said we could. Boy did we luck out as our room was beautifully decorated and all fresh and sparkling new. We had an oceanfront room, though we hadn't paid for it. the hotel seemed deserted and was very quiet. I guess they don't volunteer that some of the rooms are newer than others and try to stick you with an older one unless you ask. The best part of our room was the bed. I guess the Marriott has their own version of a "Heavenly Bed," like the Westin. This bed was so much better than and heavenly bed I've been in. It was so comfortable and had a featherbed on top of the mattress, which was brand new. (Still had the tags) The sheets were high-cotton count and it had a down comfoter with a sateen duvet. The bed was truly amazing. What we didn't like about the hotel: 1. The grounds layout is very spread out and you have to travel through several building hallways to get to the main lobby. We were literally passing hallway, after hallway to get to the elevator to get to the lobby. Seemed like it took forever. We didn't see any carts to take us anywhere. We got lost several tiimes and I have a great sense of direction! 2. There is no beach at the Marriott. Just rocky cliffs which was scenic but we wanted a sandy beach. 3. The pools are really far from one another and they are cold. We appreciate heated pools. Again, this has to do with the layout and the location of our room but it was a 5 minute walk to get to the adult pool. We like to be a little closer than that. We paid $355 per night and in retrospect wish we had booked the Fairmont, which was just a bit more expensive but have all the 5 star qualities that this one is lacking. Additionally, this hotel doesn't even hold a candle to the Marriott Ocean Club in Kaanapalli. That hotel is much nicer, much more accessible and easy to navigate.

Reviews.Title: “Wait until renovations are complete”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Beautiful grounds, Hotel is under renovation and it is amazing to me that it was allowed to run down as much as it has. Common areas are dirty and very tired. We woke up to a two inch cockroach in our bathroom. Hotel has huge potential but wait until renovations are completed.

Reviews.Title: “peaceful”
Reviews.Author: snorkler8
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a week in Maui at the Marriott in Wailea. (Dec. 4th-11th). I had read a few reviews so the construction didn't bother us. If this is your first trip to Hawaii as it was ours I will try to tell you things that might be helpful to you. If you are looking for loud night life..look somewhere else. It was quiet and peaceful. There is a really nice walking path that goes along the ocean in front of all the other resorts in Wailea. (Check out the Grand Wailea..beautiful but busy.) The hotel staff were wonderful! Very friendly and the room (which hadn't been remodeled yet)we stayed in was very clean and nice. I won't pack shampoo next year as theirs was better than the salon shampoo I normally use. I have thin, fine hair and was worried about how the ocean water would affect my hair but their shampoo and soap was great. The lotion in the room smells like mango or peach..mmmm. Food: Expensive. Wailea is a resort. We found a grocery store and did snacking. Eating out at Roy's was execelent. It was like eating a piece of artwork and so good! Dinner for 2 w/o drinks but with desert was about $90. One night we ate at "Da Kitchen" Lots of food, kind greasy..about $24 for 2. Next visit we want to drive up to Liahana (about 45-60 min. drive with traffic) to eat at "Bubba Gumps". One day we just bought 4 different types of fish and BBQ on the beach. Great fish in Maui!! Snorkeling: If you know what you are doing you can get in right in front of the hotel on the rocks. Be careful as you don't even feel it and you are bleeding from the coral. If you want to be more careful walk eather direction on the path and get in at the beach. It wasn't real clear but good enough. It was really cool to swim with the hugh turtles. I didn't see an eel but a friend did. The water is perfect temputure and the waves at the beach are great for body surfing. In Dec. I think the waves are for the more experienced surfers. Non-water: I saw the turtles everyday sitting on the lounge chairs, even saw some dolphins. I talked to people who saw the whales but it seems that I just missed them each time they surfaced. We drove up the road to Liahana and beyond. We found this "Rainforest", parked the car on a little turnout, found the path that walks through it which leads you to a quiet little cove you can snorkel and watch surfers not far away. (We watched part of the Billa Bong Women's competition) WARNING...do not drive back to Wailea via this highway. If you continue on this skinny highway it gets much skinnier. The road narrows to one lane with mountain on one side and drop off on the other side. Beautiful but terrifing! We were really glad to get off that road! We didn't make it to Hana but others that had done both roads said the road to Hana was a piece of cake compared to this road. Taking home stuff: You can only take pineapple if you get it "airport ready". Sorry no mango, coconuts are OK. We got stuff for the kids and friends from K-mart. We may have been able to get the plain and chocolate covered nuts cheaper at Costco but we ran out of time. K-mart was OK, especially for cheap t-shirts. Would we go again...and stay in the Marriott? In a heartbeat!!

Reviews.Title: “great service”
Reviews.Author: leesh
Reviews.Content: My family stayed at the marriott Oct 28th to Nov 1st! The property is undergoing a remodel- so it was very quiet and practically empty. We had the pool to ourselves one morning. The bell staff and front desk staff were great. The location is wonderful and the beaches are great for families. You can pay much more at the Grand Wailea and get a much busier resort. If you want peace and quiet try the marriott. It will surely be more expensive once the remodel is finished.

Reviews.Title: “Good price for the area, but not for the accomidations”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed here in October for our honeymoon, and had a pretty good experience. The grounds are very nice, and while you don't have any beaches, its a really quick walk to them. You're also in a good location- shops nearby, and some great restaurants (do NOT miss Nick's Fish Market!). There are renovations going on, but you don't really hear anything. However, the rooms (we got an "ocean view"- view of the pool) were only so-so...probably what you'd expect from an average (and less expensive) Marriott. While the other reviewers are right that you get "free" internet, they fail to mention that its part of a mandatory $15/day activity fee, which just seems a sneaky way to get money out of you to me. While I don't regret my choice in staying here, if I had to do it again I'd either splurge and stay at one of the fancier resorts or I'd go for a B&B.

Reviews.Title: “Couples, go HERE! You won't regret it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed in the Wailea Marriot for a full week from the 13th to the 20th of October 2005. It was WONDERFUL!!!!! We stayed in an ocean-front room that was very reasonably priced BECAUSE they're doing renovations on buildings that we never saw or heard! We specifically asked for a quiet room away from the renovations, and I would have to say we got the best room they have. We walked down the sidewalk that runs along the ocean and saw what are supposed to be the best places to stay, and in no way was I envious. Our hotel was perfect for us -- quiet, neat, lovely, no crowds -- when we would go to the lovely edgeless pool, or to sit in the jacuzzi next to it, there would be nobody, or at most, 2 families there. Very few children, as their children's pool with bells and whistles is now not open, due to renovation. The grounds are lovely, and kept pristine. Our room was fresh and clean every day. The ladies who clean it do an excellent job. The sandy beach is a stone's throw from our lanai, in both directions. Due to this season, too, I'm sure, we nearly had the beach to ourselves, unless we walked down the path too far and strayed to the ritzy resorts with all their cabanas. That place was packed!! Nope, we liked our end much better. The staff at our place was very helpful and accomodating. They provided an internet room free (due to renovations? All this fuss about renovations that never once affected our experience!!) If I were to do it again, I would go back here without a second thought. I feel like 2316 is "our" room and it's waiting for our return. Don't bother to rent snorkles at the store, rent from the resort - you can rent by the day. BUT, Snorkle-Bob's has great shirts to take back to the kids. Also, Bad---- Coffee, which is not far from the airport, is in front of a great little walk-through open air market where you can purchase a huge assortment of reasonably priced souvenirs on your way back to the airport. Give yourself an hour, you won't want to leave too quickly. Do NOT get the souvenirs at the luau! You'll find a lot of the same stuff here much cheaper! We did not eat at the Wailea Marriot. One of the restaurants was closed and the poolside food was pricey. We would pick up muffins or danishes at the grocery store daily before we would go back, and have them and the coffee provided by the hotel in the room, out on our lanai for breakfast. We got a cheap styrofoam cooler at the kmart and put lunch meats into it and cold drinks for a dollar for a half dozen at the store. This was for convenience's sake. We found that trying to read the guide books and figure out where was good food got very ponderous after a couple days, and we would often find ourselves where food wasn't convenient. Roy's was the one excellent dinner that WAS really ALL it was cracked up to be -- food was super, texture, color, and their chocolate souffle is to die for.

Reviews.Title: “Visually stunning”
Reviews.Author: Jd318us
Reviews.Content: I spent 3 nights at this property last week. It is one of the most beautiful resorts I've ever seen. I never got tired of the views and each one is unique. There is construction going on 7 days a week, but it is confined to one far end and didn't affect me in the least. The staff was very nice and the pool area is great. There are 2 nice beaches within an easy walk and a good selection of rentable snorkle gear available. The one thing I found that needed help was the bed. The mattress was so bad I could feel the springs every time I turned. That being said, I have no reservations about recommending this resort. The local restaurant choices are so-so, and definately not within walking distance. A rental car is a must, as Wailea is pretty far from most everything on Maui, which is a plus in itself.

Reviews.Title: “Laid back atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: Tuturuga
Reviews.Content: Stayed here during our honeymoon. The landscape is beautifull. Loved the infinity pool and jacuzzi. Not that it matter to us, but the kids pool was undergoing renovation. Our room was large, nice and clean. We had the ocean front deluxe suite room. The staff was friendly and accomodating. Very laid back atmosphere and not as crowded as other hotels along the strip. Probably because they are undergoing a renovation in some of the towers, which we did not hear any noise when we were there. Located very close to the Shops at Wailea. Had dinner at Longhi's, it was so..so.. Nice walkway next to the ocean connecting all the hotels and beaches. No beach directly in front of the hotel, but walking distance to Ulua Beach and Wailea Beach. We like Ulua Beach better. Can't wait to go back when the rooms are done with their renovation.

Reviews.Title: “not a bad place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Not bad for the price. The rooms are good. The resort is very spread out. It shows its age in areas. The resort has great location next to shops. The pools are nice the kids really like the kids pool. Not many people there because of remodeling. We had a good time there. Its average resort hotel and you realize how average after you see the Grand Wailea resort. The Grand Wailea is very nice. Before you stay check on remodeling some pools will be closed.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing resort!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing resort- we stayed for a week on our honeymoon in June '05 and absolutely LOVED it! They started by upgrading us from a garden-view room to an oceanfront room with a balcony just b/c we were on our honeymoon. The room was beautiful and the terrace was 100 feet from the ocean (we watched multiple sunsets from there). There are several pools around the resort including a beautiful infinity pool and a set of waterslides. Get a breakfast-included package if you can, the breakfast buffet otherwise costs $25 but is AWESOME (I can't even tell you how much stuff they have- not enough room on this review!). This resort is right next door to the Grand Wailea, which is admittedly a much fancier resort-- but it's also much more crowded. At the Marriott, we had no problem getting chairs around the pool, and it was never too crowded with kids etc. We would definitely return to this resort if we're back in the area!

Reviews.Title: “Very quiet and peaceful”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This place is going through remodeling and was very relaxing. The rooms need some updating but the pools are nice. There is no beach in front of this hotel so you have to walk about 5minutes to get to a beach. The breakfast is awesome, be sure to purchase the resort activity passport, it's worth it........free breakfast, free parking, discount tickets on luau, etc..... Night life is non-existant, so you'll have to go elsewhere if you want to hear a band and have a few drinks. Staff is very friendly....including the conceige.

Reviews.Title: “Great Luau”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We didn't stay at the marriott, but we went to their luau. I would say they have one of the best locations in all of Maui. They were right on the water. And the fire dancer, he has won 3 world championships. The food was ok, but your there mostly for the entertainment. If you are going to Maui, go to this luau, if your in the area, because it's worht it.

Reviews.Title: “Impressed skeptic”
Reviews.Author: Fletch32
Reviews.Content: We arrived on August 7 and were not in a good mood. This was the first trip to Hawaii for both of us, we've just been through two months of stress leading up to our wedding (which was less than 48 hours earlier), and upon arrival, American Airlines did not deliver my wife's suitcase. So, we were in a crabby mood upon check-in. I had reserved our ocean-front room 7 months previous, and was ready to move on. But, I was informed that the rate I was quoted would only provide an ocean-front non-smoking room "if available", and currently there were none available, only smoking; or a non-smoking with partial ocean view. It felt like an upper-cut after already getting jabbed in the jaw at the airport. My wife was nearly in tears, as it appeared nothing was going right for us. So, we agreed on the smoking ocean-front for one night, then would hope for an upgrade the next day. I went to park the car while my wife watched the bags. When I got back, the bell man informed me that a non-smoking ocean-front room had magically become available. Frustrated as I was after pleading at the front desk for 10 minutes and being told there was nothing they could do, we didn't ask any more questions and went to the room. We were extremely pleased. We were in Hale 4 on the second floor, so our sliding glass door opened up to the ground level and we could walk straight out anywhere. We were glad to have a mini-fridge for beers and bottled water. As much as I despise these "resort fees" everyone is trying to hide from their nightly rates, I think we broke even. We parked ourselves; bought the Luau at the Marriott (saving about $40 off their price) and I brought my laptop to get on the internet, so we were spared ridiculous local-call charges that easily could have reach $20 as many times as we logged off and back on line. So, we think we broke even. We didn't mind walking - to the pool, parking area, Luau grounds, neighboring beaches, etc. I know people have written about how spread out the property is - but it seemed to us like all of Wailea was very walk-friendly. We walked to the Grand, and the Four Seasons for dinner. The Shops at Wailea being around the corner was a plus. The walking just wasn't an issue for us. Construction noise: Okay - Marriott's construction was not a factor. Only once did we notice commotion, when we were by the front desk and noticed a forklift moving stacks of mattresses to the big tower. Otherwise - the biggest construction racket was caused by the villas and condos being built between the Marriott and Grand, in front of the Shops at Wailea. Too bad for Longhi's, Tommy Bahama, Ruth's Chris, etc. - because their view is getting WRECKED by these new villas. We don't have kids, but whomever did and were at the kids pools at the Marriott dealt with some serious construction noise! I would imagine that folks in Hale 6 and 7 dealt with this too during the day, and may be following my good review with a bad one. But, we didn't get bothered. Our pool time was spent at the main pool, and it was beautiful. Great hot tubs to soak in after sunset. Plus, we brought a cooler of beer to the pool - at first trying to be sneaky, not knowing if we were breaking any rules. Soon enough, the waitress just asked us to pour our beers into plastic cups and to please throw the cans away. Is that all? Thanks!! We tipped her $5 for doing nothing but being cool about it. The Hula Moon breakfast was something that surprised us, as I had read no review of this coming in. Even at $23 per person, it was excellent! One of my Maui-expert friends practically demanded that we go to the Grand Wailea breakfast buffet, saying it was the best of the best. Well ... here's what Hula Moon's included for $23 that the Grand DID NOT for $25: champagne, pancakes, waffles, little 3-4oz. cuts of New York Strip steak, and a bread pudding dessert. Plus ... a better view. From Hula Moons you see the ocean, Lanai, Kahaloowe and Molokini. From the Grand you see the pool and palm trees, with the ocean somewhere behind them. All we had was breakfast at Hula Moons, not dinner or anything else, but we considered that a highly underestimated and under-hyped aspect of the resort. The Luau was very nice - but we've been to no others and have nothing to compare it to. Very friendly staff, good food (nothing outstanding or worth a great rave, but good) and an entertaining show with a fire-twirler who was billed as the "3-time world champion" of fire twirling. With Mai Tais flowing non-stop and the sun setting from behind, it was a memorable outing. Also something I didn't read about here on TA: there are two washing machines and two dryers in Hale 7 for resort guests. Had we known about it before hand, it would have drastically changed the way we packed. As it was, we still washed many items and were greatful we discovered them. I complain constantly, and know there are things I frowned on when I was out there, but I just can't think of anything now as standing out. I do remember the carpet being the nastiest I've seen in any hotel in America, but I know they're fixing that up soon. The parking spots were designed for European minis and all the cars there were full-size or vans, so it's one of those deals where you park and have virtually no room to open your door. We wished kids were kept to a kids pool, so we could just lounge peacefully with our cocktails without fear of a ball hitting us in the head, or some 9 year old doing a cannonball off the side of the pool and splashing everyone ... but, maybe that's just a honeymooner's prejudice against distracting quiet-killers. On the whole - very high marks for this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Get ready to walk a bit”
Reviews.Author: limouser
Reviews.Content: My wife and I and another couple in our 40s stayed at the Wailea in June. My wife and travel extensively for business (I'm a Platinum with Marriot) so we've experienced good and bad. First thing is to be sure to pack your swim clothes or shorts in a easy place to get to because the odds are pretty good your room will not be ready when you get there. The rooms are definitely outdated but relatively clean. If you get stuck in one of the far out buildings it is a pretty good walk to get to the lobby where one has to go to get your car. One of our rooms was not ready until 7pm that night so they comp'd the four of us dinner at their premier restaurant. That ended up being the best dinner of the whole trip and we had dinner at some highly recommended restaurants in both Maui and Oahu. Our room wasn't up to par and it took a day to get that resolved. I've read reviews regarding prices. Anyone who is a price watcher, don't bother going to Hawaii. Hawaii is expensive no matter where you go and you just have to accept that or find somewhere on the mainland to go and stay in a Motel 6. There is construction going on so be sure to request a building on the opposite side from the renovations. The spa is only so-so according to the wives, so your time would probably be better spend shopping. All in all, it is ok, just not great.

Reviews.Title: “Loved, Loved, Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was a great hotel. It perfectly met my expectations of how I dreamed Hawaii would be. We stayed at an Aston hotel (Paypaka) the first night and moved (murphy bed, a/c and tv wouldn't work together 1/2 tub bath) -- the Marriott was a completely different world. I could have spent all my vacation time at the hotel it was so wonderful. They had beautiful lobby, gardens/waterfall landscaping on grounds, pool w/ restaurant and bar, beach chairs, excellent beach for swimming, sunbathing and snorkeling.

Reviews.Title: “Good bargain. Read my detailed review!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband & I just returned from Maui. We stayed 7 nights at this hotel. We'd been there 5 yrs ago as honeymooners when the hotel was still called "Outrigger Wailea." We think it was a bargain compared to all the other hotels in the Wailea area. I agree w/ other's comments about the openness and not feeling crowded. We stayed at an oceanfront room ground floor and were at a unit that was one of the closest to the ocean. The room was a pukey green and definitely outdated but clean. The website and brochures had said we'd get bathrobes but we had to ask for ours (no slippers though). There is optional turndown service (which you have to request) but I wouldn't bother. This is currently NOT the kind of hotel that fits with this service. (We love turndown service but when it matches the hotel amenities). Because it's so spread out, you potentially have to do a LOT of walking to get to the lobby/parking/concierge. Compared to the other hotels near it (Four seasons, Grand Wailea), the Marriott is definitely below their standards. I'd give it a 3 star. But I can't complain because we paid around $270 a night for ocean front (as a Marriott Rewards member) and you can't get that price for ocean front in peak season anywhere else at the surrounding hotels. Their mandatory resort fee was a waste of $15 a day. Supposedly, it includes "free" valet parking (but you end up tipping and I think it's a conspiracy to keep their valets getting business but we're suckers for valet so ended up tipping about $6-8/day extra) and one appetizer per room (but we never went because the hours were restricted (eg 3-5pm at the poolside grill) and it's not like you go to their restaurants just to share one appetizer and then leave). It's a way to try to make you eat at their restaurants and targets dinner time but we're mostly vegetarian and their menus for vegetarians sounds unappetizing (their only dinner entree was tofu w/veggies--and costs about $19--no thanks!!! We'd rather spend that money at a restaurant w/ better food and selections). They also have a luau which we went to 5 yrs ago and didn't go to this time. I heard they are going to stop it though and build a restaurant there instead. Might as well. It was an average luau. We never ordered room service bcause as stated above, their vegetarian options were limited and it costs MORE to order room service than to actually go to their restaurants to eat and get 'serviced'. There's a 20% mandatory fee added to the order and on top of that a $3 fee. I'm not sure if they want tip for the delivering person as well--probably. You don't even get your water glasses filled or any waiter service and you are essentially paying over 20% above the total to just have some food delivered. Unless you are comatose or bed slugs (or newlyweds), I'd advise trekking outside of your room for food. There is no beach and only rocks at the oceanfront of the hotel but we were fine w/that. You could walk to a nearby beach. They are also doing renovations right now but they are localized right now to towers near the lobby--which we were far away from so we didn't hear a peep. Hopefully, they'll do a great job updating the rooms and decor. The service was so-so. We had a male concierge who practically pressured us to go w/Aloha Blue for the Molokini snorkel trip. He discouraged us from using other boats and didn't give us any options. It cost about $85 dollars and we didn't think it was worth it. The captain and crew were pretty nice though. The boat fits around 30 people and was VERY choppy. My husband was seasick as were a few others. The concierge also told us they have a good lunch for vegetarians and it was NOT true. There were a few cold veggieburgers (no grill) and a pasta salad. I wonder if the concierge gets kickbacks from recommending this charter. It turns out we met another Marriott couple who had been sent their by the concierge too. We found the concierges at Marriott definitely subpar (we interacted with 2-3 of them). They didn't seem knowledgeable, did not seem interested, and didn't give us much options (they would jump to their favored "brand" and were not interested in discussing the others--sort of pooh-poohed the others). So I wouldn't use them or use them with a grain of salt and a lot of independent research and DON'T get pressured into bowing to their "expertise". The staff at Marriott were OK but not outstanding or excellent. I'd give them a good rating. Once they update the hotel appearance wise, they should update their staff too to be more professional, helpful, knowledgeable. There was one valet who was great (greeted my husband by name). The staff are decently friendly and not snooty. Overall, we paid 3 star prices (for Wailea that is--it's a pricey hotel area) and got 3 star rooms (in terms of appearance), service. So we can't complain. We were happy with our fantastic view which was 5 star view so we think we got a good bargain. Once they finish the renovations, I bet they'll raise their prices to be more comparable w/other hotels in the area but need to work on their amenities and staff training and services to justify the increase. They have a nice looking spa which we didn't use and the exercise room was pretty nice. Bring your own water (from Costco near the airport) because the Evian bottles in the room cost almost $5/bottle. Happy traveling! PS. Bring bug repellant--especially in the summer!!! I got bitten during the day near the pool (near hedges) and in the evening they latch onto you even if you are vigorously swinging your arms and legs. We both got multiple mosquitoe bites daily until we invested in some DEET and sprayed even during the day.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Not sure what the complaints are all about as the resort has beautiful grounds and good food. Yes, there is renovation going on but that only made noise during mid day if you were in the tower. My wife and I were there for our anniversary and management sent us a bottle of Champagne and upgraded our room without us even asking. Staff was pleasant and gave us some referals to places to eat and drink in Kihei that they visit when not working. Great sunsets off the rocks. Negatives: Mandatory $15/day fee?1? - Just add it in the price!!! Beaches were not on premise and down a short ocean front path Also, one of the two hot tubs was TOO HOT!

Reviews.Title: “Maui Wonderland”
Reviews.Author: Boo1
Reviews.Content: This hotel is perhaps the most impressive property I have ever stayed in. From the gardens to the pools to the buffets...it is simply wonderful! It is located right on the oceanfront and has a wonderful view of the island. There are several pools to choose from and lots of recreational activities to take part in. We loved it and can't wait to go back.

Reviews.Title: “Wailea Marriott Saved Our Trip”
Reviews.Author: lllondon1
Reviews.Content: After staying at the Maui Prince, we decided to stay the last part of our trip in West Maui at the Kaanapali Beach Hotel which was a big mistake. I called several hotels that were completely full and thought the rest of our trip would be miserable until I was able to book a room at the Wailea Marriott. We drove down early that afternoon and were able to check in immediately. We got upgraded to an oceanview room that met all of our needs. It was very spacious, had a mini-fridge for drinks and snacks, and a nice bathroom. The location was great and our son really enjoyed the children's pool and slides. We went snorkeling right off the beach. The paths and grounds around the hotel were pleasant to walk at night and it was very convenient to the Shops at Wailea. We would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Just Returned! Fabulous 6 Nights at Wailea Marriott Resort on Maui”
Reviews.Author: SunK
Reviews.Content: As most of you probably do, I attempt read as many reviews and travel guides as possible before I book my trips, this one was no exception. I decided to take the risk and book my stay at the Wailea Marriott (â€œWMâ€�) despite some previous reviewer negative comments about room condition and ongoing construction. The decision was a good one. We just returned (6/19/05) from a wonderful and relaxing stay at this resort (check out my photos of the WM, taken last week). To summarize our feelings about this resort, it is all a matter of what you prefer, we like warm friendly environments that are not over-done. We like staying at places that cater to us with a friendly staff, resorts or hotels whose clientele is interested in relaxing and not impressing you or themselves with their social status. The WM is our kind of place and currently a great value, donâ€™t wait or you will miss it. Construction: We found it to be almost non-existent. During our stay, all 4 pools (except slide at main pool) and restaurants were operational. The construction was under way in the Haleakala Tower with little physical evidence except occasional pounding (daylight hours only) heard in the area of the main reception entrance. There was more construction noise heard from the condo construction next door, but again, it was during the day and more obvious to residents of the Grand Wailea (â€œGWâ€�) (more on this resort later), two doors down from the WM. Room Cost & Condition: Our Oceanfront room in building Hale 7 (Hale means house in Hawaiian) was roomy and very clean, not worn but well maintained, they are upgrading these rooms but for the $ paid a good value, and very nice. We booked our travel package via Northwest Airlines MLT Vacations. The package included air, convertible car rental and an â€œoceanview king roomâ€� with daily breakfast for 2 (more on this later) included. I calculated, considering the best deals I could book separately on the airfare & car, the king room w/breakfast cost under $250/night including tax. I paid the $15.00/night mandatory resort fee separately. We arrived @ 6:00 PM and were quickly greeted by a very friendly staff, the receptionist immediately upgraded us (without us requesting) to a third floor OCEANFRONT room. Like so many prior reviews we read, we thought the upgrade was unlikely, but it proved out to happen for us, our room was literally ~100â€™ from the Pacific Ocean. The king bed mattress was used, but did not sag and was comfortable.
